title: Vagad
text:
Vagad (also known as Vagar, <a href="Hindi">Hindi</a>: वागड) is a <a href="List%20of%20regions%20in%20India">region</a> in southeastern <a href="Rajasthan">Rajasthan</a> state of western <a href="India">India</a>. Its boundaries are roughly defined by those of the districts of <a href="Dungarpur%20district">Dungarpur</a> and <a href="Banswara%20district">Banswara</a>. Major cities of the region are <a href="Dungarpur">Dungarpur</a> and <a href="Banswara">Banswara</a>.
Geography.
Vagad is bounded on the north by <a href="Mewar">Mewar</a> region of Rajasthan, on the southeast and eastby <a href="Malwa">Malwa</a> region of <a href="Madhya%20Pradesh">Madhya Pradesh</a>, and on the west and southwest by <a href="Gujarat">Gujarat</a> state. The region mostly lies in the upper watershed of the <a href="Mahi%20River">Mahi River</a> and its tributaries, which is said to be the lifeline of Vagad. The Mahi flows north through the district (Banswara) from its origin in the <a href="Vindhya%20Range">Vindhya Range</a> of Madhya Pradesh, entering the district (Banswara) from the southeast and flowing north towards the northern end of the district, where it turns southwest to form the boundary between Banswara and Dungarpur districts before entering Gujarat and emptying into the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Cambay">Gulf of Cambay</a>.
Vagad has rich <a href="flora%20%28plants%29">flora</a> and <a href="fauna%20%28animals%29">fauna</a>. The <a href="forest">forest</a>s include mainly <a href="teak">teak</a>. The <a href="wildlife">wildlife</a> includes a large variety of wild animals such as the <a href="leopard">leopard</a> and the <a href="chinkara">chinkara</a>. Common <a href="birds">birds</a> in the region include <a href="fowl">fowl</a>, <a href="partridge">partridge</a>, <a href="black%20drongo">black drongo</a>, <a href="grey%20shrike">grey shrike</a>, green <a href="bee-eater">bee-eater</a>, <a href="bulbul">bulbul</a> and <a href="parrot">parrot</a>. Some of the towns in this region are Aspur, Bhiluda, Simalwada, Sagwara, Partapur, Bagidra and Garhi.
History.
Parmar rulers held Vagar during the 11th century with their political center at <a href="Arthuna">Arthuna</a> (in present-day <a href="Banswara%20district">Banswara district</a>). Vagad as a different region separated from <a href="Mewar">Mewar</a>, and a branch of <a href="Guhilot">Guhilot</a> <a href="Rajput">Rajput</a> ruled here 
All princely states were merged into Rajasthan prior to 1947.
